@antoniogm @digime Actually this is one area one cannot criticise FB. At @digime we have been enabling individuals to download their FB data for years for themselves and then to onshare to others (with full FB approval)
@antoniogm @digime Looking not looming!

@antoniogm @digime Agreed, but perhaps the issue is looming at data categories in isolation - think whole person, whole data set - and see the innovation possibilities open up. So whilst you can argue which bits of GDPR are positive or negative, the whole is a big spur to innovation

@rangerj @digime You mean FB should open up their data and....have an open platform where third-party devs can, with user permission, use data in other applications? Like the FB platform that CA hacked? :) 

I'm convinced that with FB, people will always howl for what they once howled against.
@rangerj @digime Ok, but health data is a whole different kettle of fish. Even in the US, that sort of data is subject to strict regulation.

@antoniogm @digime Key I believe is thinking way beyond Facebook, Google at al to the much wider ecosystem of all businesses interacting with individuals- now any business can get better data than FB, G at al on an individual to provide new services (with consent)

@antoniogm @digime It is more fundamental than that. We share very limited data today - open up the data silos, enable "private sharing" from the individual and you share much much more data with consequent economic growth. Happening today and I could give you many examples

@rangerj @digime Ok. Of everything in the GDPR, the data portability thing *might* be a net ecosystem win in that it undermines the network effects propping up incumbents.

It also might create chaos as a thousand dinky networks crop up (Dogster!), people churn like mad, and everything fragments.

@antoniogm @digime 3 of 3. This "private sharing" of Rich personal data (wider, deeper, 100% accurate, consented) solves systemic issues of data availability in health for example, but also across all consumer interactions

@antoniogm @digime 2 of 3 Then businesses approach individual directly for better data (thro likes of @digime - see https://t.co/VBAwO557x9) which can even be processed locally on users device - means more likely to share as private
@antoniogm @digime 1 of 2: Data Portability right means I individuals have opportunity to get complete data set about themselves- so have much much richer data than any other party

@rangerj @digime How does regulation of a thing create more of that thing happening?

What will you be able to do under GDPR (other than perhaps signaling your compliance) that you can't do now?

@antoniogm 2 of 2. Also be aware that GDPR will actually INCREASE personal data sharing but privately - see @digime for details or message me - GDPR is good for all tech companies if you think the individual
